# Color wheel compass {.hiddenheading #cwc}

{{< include /dec/_color.qmd >}}

The [colorğŸ¨wheel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Color_wheel#:~:text=an%20abstract%20illustrative%20organization%20of%20color%20hues%20around%20a%20circle) compassğŸ§­above indicates both a [hue](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hue#:~:text=an%20angular%20position%20around%20a%20central%20or%20neutral%20point%20or%20axis%20on%20a%20color%20space%20coordinate%20diagram) in [mt](#mt){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="milliturns"} and a course in [mr](#mr).tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="milliroses"}. We can convert the hue to [HSL and HSV](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HSL_and_HSV#:~:text=the%20two%20most%20common%20cylindrical%2Dcoordinate%20representations%20of%20points%20in%20an%20RGB%20color%20model) degrees ([hÂ°](#deg){#huedegree .tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="HSL or HSV degrees"}) and the course to compassğŸ§­degrees ([cÂ°](#deg){#compassdegree .tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="compass degrees"}): 25 [mr](#mr){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="milliroses"} = 9 [cÂ°](#deg){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="compass degrees"}. To rotateğŸ”„the colorğŸ¨wheel compassğŸ§­, use the "Hue" [range](https://observablehq.com/framework/inputs/range)ğŸšï¸and [hue bar](https://observablehq.com/@paavanb/progressive-color-picker) inputs beneath it or change the course from Point [0]{.point0} to [1]{.point1} on the mapğŸ—ºï¸.

# Red green blue (rgb) {.hiddenheading #rgb}

The table beneath the hue bar compares the current Point [0]{.point0} to [1]{.point1} course in its top row with the [cardinal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cardinal_direction#:~:text=north%2C%20south%2C%20east%2C%20and%20west) and [intercardinal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cardinal_direction#:~:text=northeast%20(NE)%2C%20southeast%20(SE)%2C%20southwest%20(SW)%2C%20and%20northwest%20(NW)) directions. Together, the rangeğŸšï¸inputs underneath the hue bar form a "hue saturation lightness" ([hsl](#hsl){#huesaturationlightness .tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="hue saturation lightness"}) triplet. Like "[red]{.color0} [green]{.color4} [blue]{.color7}" ([rgb](#rgb)(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RGB_color_model#:~:text=an%20additive%20color%20model){#redgreenblue}) or [hexadecimal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Web_colors#Hex_triplet:~:text=hexadecimal%20number%20used%20in%20HTML%2C%20CSS%2C%20SVG%2C%20and%20other%20computing%20applications%20to%20represent%20colors) ([hex](#hex){#hexadecimal .tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="hexadecimal"}) triplets, [hsl](#hsl){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="hue saturation lightness"} triplets specify a full-fledged colorğŸ¨instead of just a hue.

::: {.callout-warning}
# Bad Pun Alert
Feeling ***disoriented***ğŸ˜µâ€ğŸ’«? Of [***course***](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Course_(navigation)#:~:text=the%20cardinal%20direction%20in%20which%20the%20craft%20is%20to%20be%20steered) you are! ColorğŸ¨labelsğŸ·ï¸can help you find your [***bearings***](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bearing_(navigation)#:~:text=the%20horizontal%20angle%20between%20the%20direction%20of%20an%20object%20and%20north%20or%20another%20object), stay on [***track***](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Course_(navigation)#:~:text=The%20path%20that%20a%20vessel%20follows), and avoid [***heading***](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Course_(navigation)#:~:text=the%20direction%20where%20the%20watercraft's%20bow%20or%20the%20aircraft's%20nose%20is%20pointed) achesğŸ¤•. [Orange]{.orange} you glad I couldn't think of a colorğŸ¨pun?
:::

ColorğŸ¨can provide a general idea of angularğŸ“[measure](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Angle#:~:text=The%20magnitude%20of%20an%20angle), regardless of the metric prefixes or [units](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Angle#Units) we use. Therefore, we can reuseâ™»ï¸colorsğŸ¨across many different contexts. Most often, [red]{.color0} designates starting points, like North ([0]{.color0} [mr](#mr){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="milliroses"}) and [Longitude 0](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/18th_meridian_west#:~:text=a%20line%20of%20longitude%20that%20extends%20from%20the%20North%20Pole%20across%20the%20Arctic%20Ocean%2C%20Greenland%2C%20Iceland%2C%20the%20Atlantic%20Ocean%2C%20the%20Canary%20Islands%2C%20the%20Southern%20Ocean%2C%20and%20Antarctica%20to%20the%20South%20Pole) ([0]{.color0} [mÎ»](#mp){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="milliparallels"}), and [cyan]{.color5} denotes midpoints, such as South ([500]{.color5} [mr](#mr){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="milliroses"}) and [Longitude 5](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/162nd_meridian_east#:~:text=a%20line%20of%20longitude%20that%20extends%20from%20the%20North%20Pole%20across%20the%20Arctic%20Ocean%2C%20Asia%2C%20the%20Pacific%20Ocean%2C%20the%20Southern%20Ocean%2C%20and%20Antarctica%20to%20the%20South%20Pole) ([500]{.color5} [mÎ»](#mp){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="milliparallels"}).

The Equator ([0]{.color0} [mm](#mm){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="millimeridians"}) is the [major latitude](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Circle_of_latitude#:~:text=mark%20the%20divisions%20between%20the%20five%20principal%20geographical%20zones) midway between the South ([-250]{.color750} [mm](#mm){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="millimeridians"}) and North ([250]{.color250} [mm](#mm){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="millimeridians"}) Poles. Unlike the Equator, the Tropics of [Cancer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tropic_of_Cancer#:~:text=northernmost%20circle%20of%20latitude%20where%20the%20Sun%20can%20be%20seen%20directly%20overhead)â™‹([65]{.color065} [mm](#mm){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="millimeridians"}) and [Capricorn](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tropic_of_Capricorn#:~:text=the%20southernmost%20latitude%20where%20the%20Sun%20can%20be%20seen%20directly%20overhead)â™‘ï¸([-65]{.color935} [mm](#mm){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="millimeridians"}) and the [Arctic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arctic_Circle#:~:text=the%20southernmost%20latitude%20at%20which%2C%20on%20the%20winter%20solstice%20in%20the%20Northern%20Hemisphere%2C%20the%20Sun%20does%20not%20rise%20all%20day%2C%20and%20on%20the%20Northern%20Hemisphere%27s%20summer%20solstice%2C%20the%20Sun%20does%20not%20set) ([250]{.color250} [mm](#mm){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="millimeridians"} -- [65]{.color065} [mm](#mm){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="millimeridians"} = [185]{.color185} [mm](#mm){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="millimeridians"}) and [Antarctic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antarctic_Circle#:~:text=the%20Sun%20is%20above%20the%20horizon%20for%2024%20continuous%20hours%20at%20least%20once%20per%20year%20(and%20therefore%20visible%20at%20solar%20midnight)%20and%20the%20centre%20of%20the%20Sun%20(ignoring%20refraction)%20is%20below%20the%20horizon%20for%2024%20continuous%20hours%20at%20least%20once%20per%20year%20(and%20therefore%20not%20visible%20at%20solar%20noon)) ([65]{.color065} [mm](#mm){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="millimeridians"} -- [250]{.color250} [mm](#mm){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="millimeridians"} = [-185]{.color815} [mm](#mm){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="millimeridians"}) Circles are defined by the [axial tilt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Axial_tilt#Earth:~:text=the%20angle%20between%20the%20ecliptic%20and%20the%20celestial%20equator%20on%20the%20celestial%20sphere) of the EarthğŸŒ: [65]{.color065} [mt](#mt){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="milliturns"}.

# Dec time zones {.hiddenheading #dtz}

Enable the â€œGridâ€ toggleâœ…input to see Latitudes [-2](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/72nd_parallel_south#:~:text=a%20circle%20of%20latitude%20that%20is%2072%20degrees%20south%20of%20the%20Earth's%20equatorial%20plane%20in%20the%20Antarctic) ([-200]{.color8} [mm]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="millimeridians"}), [-1](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/36th_parallel_south#:~:text=a%20circle%20of%20latitude%20that%20is%2036%20degrees%20south%20of%20the%20Earth's%20equatorial%20plane) ([-100]{.color9} [mm](#mm){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="millimeridians"}), [0](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equator#:~:text=the%20circle%20of%20latitude%20that%20divides%20Earth%20into%20the%20Northern%20and%20Southern%20hemispheres) ([0]{.color0} [mm](#mm){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="millimeridians"}), [1](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/36th_parallel_north#:~:text=a%20circle%20of%20latitude%20that%20is%2036%20degrees%20north%20of%20the%20Earth's%20equatorial%20plane) ([100]{.color1} [mm](#mm){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="millimeridians"}), and [2](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/72nd_parallel_north#:~:text=a%20circle%20of%20latitude%20that%20is%2072%20degrees%20north%20of%20the%20Earth's%20equatorial%20plane%2C%20in%20the%20Arctic) ([200]{.color2} [mm](#mm){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="millimeridians"}) on the mapğŸ—ºï¸above along with the ten major longitudes that divide the EarthğŸŒinto the ten Dec time zones. Notably, Longitude [0]{.color0} is the major longitude that functions as both the [Prime Meridian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_meridian#:~:text=an%20arbitrarily%2Dchosen%20meridian%20%28a%20line%20of%20longitude%29%20in%20a%20geographic%20coordinate%20system%20at%20which%20longitude%20is%20defined%20to%20be%200%C2%B0) and [International Date Line](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Date_Line#:~:text=the%20line%20between%20the%20South%20and%20North%20Poles%20that%20is%20the%20boundary%20between%20one%20calendar%20day%20and%20the%20next) in Dec.

Like the ten major longitudes that separate them, Dec time zones are numbered [0]{.color0} to [9]{.color9}. Based on its current [deciparallel]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="a tenth of a parallel"} ([dÎ»](#dp){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="deciparallel"}) longitude, \${point0lHsl}, Point [0]{.point0} on the mapğŸ—ºï¸above is in Zone \${point0zHsl}. The number assigned to each time zone is its offset from Zone [0]{.color0} in [decidays]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="tenths of a day"} ([dd](#dd){#deciday .tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="decidays"}). To obtain the [dd](#dd){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="deciday"} offset at a location, we [floor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Floor_and_ceiling_functions#:~:text=the%20greatest%20integer%20less%20than%20or%20equal%20to%20x) its [dÎ»](#dp){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="deciparallel"} longitude: âŒŠ\${decLonHsl}âŒ‹ = \${decZonHsl}.

```{ojs}
//| echo: false
//| label: loninput
viewof longitude = Inputs.range([0, 10], {label: "Longitude", value: .5, step: .01})
```

Each Dec time zone is 1 [dÎ»](#dp){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="deciparallel"} wide and 0.5 [m](#m){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="meridians"} long. While 1 [m](#m){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="meridian"} is always [~]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="approximately"}1 [c](#c){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="taur"} long, the length of a [Î»](#lambda){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="parallel"} [varies by latitude](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Longitude#Length_of_a_degree_of_longitude:~:text=depends%20only%20on%20the%20radius%20of%20a%20circle%20of%20latitude). At the Equator, 1 [Î»](#lambda){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="parallel"} is [~]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="approximately"}1 [c](#c){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="taur"} long. At the [North](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_Pole#:~:text=the%20point%20in%20the%20Northern%20Hemisphere%20where%20the%20Earth%27s%20axis%20of%20rotation%20meets%20its%20surface) or [South](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Pole#:~:text=the%20point%20in%20the%20Southern%20Hemisphere%20where%20the%20Earth%27s%20axis%20of%20rotation%20meets%20its%20surface) Pole, the length of a [Î»](#lambda){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="parallel"} is zero. The approximate [c](#c){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="taur"} length of a [Î»](#lambda){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="parallel"} is the [cosine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sine_and_cosine#:~:text=the%20ratio%20of%20the%20length%20of%20the%20adjacent%20leg%20to%20that%20of%20the%20hypotenuse) of its latitude in [m](#m){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="meridians"}, [rad](#rad){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="radians"}, or [Â°](#deg){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="degrees"}, depending on the input requirement of our cosine function: cos(\${parLat}\${conversionFactor}) = \${parLen}.

```{ojs}
//| echo: false
//| label: latinput
viewof latitude = Inputs.range([-.25, .25], {label: "Latitude", value: 0, step: .001})
```

```{ojs}
//| echo: false
//| label: costype
viewof costype = Inputs.radio(["turns", "radians", "degrees"], {label: "Cosine input", value: "turns"})
```

# Dates and times {.hiddenheading #dat}

Dec dates consist of a "year of era" ([yoe](#yoe){#yearofera .tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="year of era"}) and a "day of year" ([doy](#doy){#dayofyear .tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="day of year"}), whereas Dec times are composed of a "time of day" ([tod](#tod){#timeofday .tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="time of day"}) and a "time zone offset" ([tzo](#tzo){#timezoneoffset .tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="time zone offset"}). In Zone [0]{.color0}, the current date is \${decYearP0hsl0}[+]{.mono}\${decDateP0hsl0} and the current time is \${decTimeP0hsl0}[-]{.mono}[0]{.color0}. ColorğŸ¨labelsğŸ·ï¸can help us to visually [parse](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parsing#:~:text=a%20process%20of%20analyzing%20a%20string%20of%20symbols) the date and time that make up a Dec snapğŸ«°: \${decYearP0hsl1}[+]{.mono}\${decDateP0hsl1}\${decTimeP0hsl1}[-]{.mono}[0]{.color0}.

# Millenium Year Day {.hiddenheading #myd}

[Yoe](#yoe){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="year of era"} colorğŸ¨labelsğŸ·ï¸are based on [y](#y){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="year"}. Every millennium starts with Year 0 ([0]{.color0} [y](#y){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="year"}) and has Year 500 ([500]{.color5} [y](#y){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="year"}) as its midpoint. [Doy](#doy){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="day of year"} colorğŸ¨labelsğŸ·ï¸are derived from [milliyears]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="thousandths of a year"} ([my](#my){#milliyear .tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="milliyears"}). Every year starts on [Day 0]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="March 1"} ([0]{.color0} [my](#my){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="milliyears"}). The midyear point ([500]{.color5} [my](#my){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="milliyears"}) is noon ([500]{.color5} [md](#md){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="millidays"}) on [Day 182]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="August 30"} in [common years](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Common_year#:~:text=a%20calendar%20year%20with%20365%20days) and midnight ([0]{.color0} [md](#md){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="millidays"}) on [Day 183]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="August 31"} in [leap years](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leap_year#:~:text=a%20calendar%20year%20that%20contains%20an%20additional%20day).

# Day of dek (dod) {.hiddenheading #dod}

Each [doy](#doy){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="day of year"} also has two components. The first two digits of a three-digit [doy](#doy){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="days of year"} represent a group of ten days called a [decaday](#doy){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="group of ten days"} ([dek](#dek){#decaday .tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="group of ten days"}). The last digit of a [doy]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="days of year"} is the "day of dek" ([dod](#dod){#dayofdek .tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="day of dek"}). In Dec, [deks](#dek){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="groups of ten days"} are used instead of months and weeks. Likewise, Dec uses [dod](#dod){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="days of dek"} in lieu of days of month ([dom](#dom){#dayofmonth .tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="days of month"}) and days of week ([dow](#dow){#dayofweek .tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="days of week"}). In Zone [0]{.color0}, it is currently [Dek](#dek){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="group of ten days"} \${decDekP0hsl} and [Dod](#dod){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="Day of dek"} \${decDodP0hsl}.

# Zone equatorial meter (zem) {.hiddenheading #zem}

:::{.column-page-right fig-align="center" style="text-align:center;font-size:.825rem;" id="zemmodulor" .lighthouse}
![](../asset/Modulor_measurements.svg){#zModu}
[Wikimedia](https://commons.m.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Modulor_measurements.svg#mw-jump-to-license)
:::

Apart from [c](#c){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="taur"}, Dec also measures distance using a unit called the **z**one **e**quatorial **m**eter (zem). The width of a Dec time zone at the Equator is approximately ten million ([~10^7^]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="approximately ten million"}) zem ([z](#z){#zoneequatorialmeter .tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="zem"}). Similarly, the distance from the Equator to one of the Poles is [~10^7^]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="approximately ten million"} [meters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metre#Definition:~:text=the%20base%20unit%20of%20length%20in%20the%20International%20System%20of%20Units). In other words, a [decimeridian]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="a tenth of a meridian"} ([dm](#dm){#decimeridian .tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="decimeridian"}) is [~10^7^]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="approximately ten million"} [z](#z){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="zem"} long and a [quarter meridian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Meridian_arc#Full_meridian_(polar_perimeter):~:text=The%20distance%20from%20the%20equator%20to%20the%20pole) is [~10^7^]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="approximately ten million"} meters long.

# Length area volume {.hiddenheading #lav}

You can approximate a [z](#z){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="zem"} using your handsğŸ¤². With your palms flat on a table in front of you and the tips of your thumbsğŸ‘touching, the maximum distance between the tips of your pinkies is [~]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="approximately"}1 [z](#z){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="zem"}. When you spread out the fingers on one handâœ‹or do the "[call me](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shaka_sign#:~:text=the%20gesture%20is%20commonly%20understood%20to%20mimic%20the%20handset%20of%20a%20traditional%20landline%20telephone)", "[drink](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shaka_sign#:~:text=placing%20the%20thumb%20to%20the%20mouth%20and%20motioning%20the%20little%20finger%20upward%20as%20if%20tipping%20up%20a%20bottle%27s%20bottom%20end)", or "[shaka](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shaka_sign#:~:text=a%20gesture%20with%20friendly%20intent%20often%20associated%20with%20Hawaii%20and%20surf%20culture)"ğŸ¤™gesture, your thumbğŸ‘and pinky tips are [~]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="approximately"}0.5 [z](#z){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="zems"} apart.

Alternatively, two people can stand in front of each other and raise their armsğŸ’ª, placing one handâœ‹on the elbow of the other person and the other handâœ‹on their own elbow.

The [z^2^](#z2){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="square zem"} will be between your shins, its top will be below your knees, and its bottom will be either above your ankles or feetğŸ¦¶, depending on your height.

# Typical seat height {.hiddenheading #tsh}

According to [dimensions.com](https://www.dimensions.com), 115 [centizem](#cz){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="hundredths of a zem"} ([cz](#cz){#centizem .tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="centizem"}) is the [typical seat height](https://www.dimensions.com/element/sitting-female-side-1#:~:text=Seat%20Height%20(Typical)%3A-,18%E2%80%9D%20%7C%2046%20cm,-Style%3A%20Casual) for both men and women age 25 to 45. A boxğŸ“¦that is the size of a cubic [zem](#z){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="zone equatorial meter"} ([z^3^](#z3){#cubiczem .tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="cubic zem"}) would likely fit under a typical chairğŸª‘ or in between the shins of two people sitting in front of each other with their knees and feetğŸ¦¶1 [z](#z){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="zem"} apart and their legsğŸ¦µbent at 25 [centiturn]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="a hundredth of a turn"} ([ct](#ct){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="centiturn"}) anglesğŸ“.

# Perpetually setting sun {.hiddenheading #pss}

In [Slovak](https://sk.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zem)ğŸ‡¸ğŸ‡°, [zem](#z){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="zone equatorial meter"} means EarthğŸŒ. This is fitting because all Dec units are based on physical attributes of the EarthğŸŒ. At the Equator, the EarthğŸŒrotates on its axis at a speed of [~]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="approximately"}1.00224 [v](#v){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="omegars"}. If we could indefinitely maintain this speed while flying West in an airplaneâœˆï¸towards the setting sunâ˜€ï¸, we would be able to perpetually fly [into the sunset](https://tvtropes.org/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RidingIntoTheSunset)ğŸŒ….

# Airplane cruising speed {.hiddenheading #acs}

To travel fast enough for a perpetual sunsetğŸŒ…, the airplaneâœˆï¸would need to surpass the [speed of sound](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Speed_of_sound#:~:text=the%20distance%20travelled%20per%20unit%20of%20time%20by%20a%20sound%20wave)ğŸ”Š([sos](#sos){#speedofsound .tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="speed of sound"}), which at 15 [Â°](#deg){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="degrees"} [Celsius](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Celsius#:~:text=the%20unit%20of%20temperature%20on%20the%20Celsius%20temperature%20scale) and 1 [standard atmosphere](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Standard_atmosphere_(unit)#:~:text=a%20unit%20of%20pressure%20defined%20as%20101325%20Pa) is 0.735048 [v](#v){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="omegars"} or Mach 1. [Mach numbers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mach_number) are relative to the [sos](#sos){#speedofsound .tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="speed of sound"}, which varies greatly by air temperature and pressure. The cruising speed of a [Boeing 747](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing_747#:~:text=sweep%2C%20allowing%20a-,Mach%C2%A00.85,-%28490%C2%A0kn;%20900) is [~]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="approximately"}0.54 [v](#v){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="omegars"} or Mach [~]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="approximately"}0.85.

The highwayğŸ›£ï¸speed of a carğŸš—is roughly tenfold slower than the cruising speed of an airplaneâœˆï¸. If we are driving on a highwayğŸ›£ï¸at a speed of 50 [mv](#mv){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="milliomegars"} and our exit is 1000 [z](#z){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="zems"} away, we will have 20 [centimillidays](#cmd){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="hundred thousandths of a day"} ([cmd](#cmd){#centimilliday .tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="centimilliday"}) until we have to exit the highwayğŸ›£ï¸. To ensure we do not miss our exit, we can periodically check a countdown of the remaining [z](#z){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="zems"}: \${zLeft}.

# Centimilliday (cmd) {.hiddenheading #cmd}

Dec refers to a [centimilliday](#cmd){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="a hundred thousandth of a day"} as a [beat]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="hundred thousandths of a day"} ([b](#b){#beat .tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="beats"}) because it is similar in duration to a heartâ¤ï¸beat or [musical beat](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beat_(music)#:~:text=I-,n%20music%20and%20music%20theory%2C%20the%20beat%20is%20the%20basic%20unit%20of%20time,-%2C%20the). A [d](#d){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="day"} is 100 [centiday]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="hundredths of a day"} ([cd](#cd){#centiday .tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="centidays"}), [10^5^]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="a hundred thousand"} [b](#b){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="beats"}, or [10^6^]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="a million"} [microdays]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="millionths of a day"} ([Âµd](#ud){#microday .tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="microdays"}). One [mc](#mc){#millitaur .tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="millitaur"} is 100 [kilozem]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="thousands of zem"} ([kz](#kz){#kilozem .tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="thousands of zems"}), [10^5^]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="a hundred thousand"} [z](#z){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="zems"}, [10^6^]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="a million"} [decizems]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="tenths of a zem"} ([dz](#dz){#decizem .tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="decizems"}), or [10^6^]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="a million"} [nanotaurs]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="millionths of a taur"} ([nc](#nc){#nanotaur .tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="nanotaurs"}). Therefore, [mv](#mv){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="milliomegar"} = $\text{mc}\over\text d$ = $\text {kz}\over\text {cd}$ = $\text z\over\text b$ = $\text {dz}\over\text{Âµd}$ = $\text {nc}\over\text{Âµd}$. A [cd]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="centiday"} is [96%]{.color960} of a quarter hour and a [b](#b){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="beat"} is [86.4%]{.color864} of a second.

# heart rate tempo {.hiddenheading #hrt}

A [normal resting heartâ¤ï¸rate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heart_rate#:~:text=heart%20rate%20is-,60â€“100%20bpm,-.%20An%20ultra%2Dtrained) is between 100 and 166.[6]{.vinculum} [b](#b){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="beats"} per [md](#md){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="millidays"} ([bpm](#bpm){#beatspermilliday .tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="beats per milliday"}). The unofficial anthem of the Dec measurement system, "[Turn the beat around](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Turn_the_Beat_Around#:~:text=a%20disco%20song%20written%20by%20Gerald%20Jackson%20and%20Peter%20Jackson%2C%20and%20performed%20by%20American%20actress%20and%20singer%20Vicki%20Sue%20Robinson%20in%201976)", has a [tempo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tempo#:~:text=the%20speed%20or%20pace%20of%20a%20given%20composition) of 188.64 [bpm](#bpm){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="beats per milliday"}, which corresponds to the _allegro_ [tempo marking](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tempo#Approximately_from_the_slowest_to_the_fastest). A Dec clockâ°ticks at a rate of 100 [bpm](#bpm){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="beats per milliday"}, $\text b^{-1}$, $1\over\text b$, 1 [inverse](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multiplicative_inverse#:~:text=x%2C%20denoted%20by-,1/x%20or%20x%E2%88%921,-%2C%20is%20a%20number) beat, or 1 perbeat ([p](#per){#perbeat .tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="perbeat"}), which is [1.15[740]{.vinculum}]{.colorIob} times more frequent than a [Hertz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hertz#:~:text=one%20event%20(or%20cycle)).

# Frequency period wavelength {.hiddenheading #fpw}

Dec uses [p](#per){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="perbeat"}, [b]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="beats"}, and [z]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="zem"}, often with metric prefixes, to measure the [frequency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frequency#:~:text=the%20number%20of%20occurrences%20of%20a%20repeating%20event%20per%20unit%20of%20time), [period](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frequency#:~:text=the%20reciprocal%20of%20the%20frequency), and [wavelength](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wavelength#:~:text=the%20distance%20over%20which%20the%20wave%27s%20shape%20repeats), respectively, of a sound or light wave. The equations below show how frequency, period, and wavelength are related to each other and to speed. The speed of light ([sol](#s){#speedoflight .tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="speed of light"}) is roughly 647.551657 [megaomegars]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="millions of omegars"} ([Mv](#v){.megaomegars .tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="megaomegars"}), which is about 881 million times faster than the [sos](#sos){#speedofsound .tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="speed of sound"}.

$$\text{frequency} = \text{speed} \div \text{wavelength} = 1 \div \text{period}$$

$$\text{period} = \text{wavelength} \div \text{speed} = 1 \div \text{frequency}$$

$$\text{wavelength} = \text{speed} \times \text{period} = \text{speed} \div \text{frequency}$$

The frequency range of the  [visible](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Visible_spectrum#:~:text=the%20band%20of%20the%20electromagnetic%20spectrum%20that%20is%20visible%20to%20the%20human%20eye) spectrum of light is [~]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="approximately"}345.6 to [~]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="approximately"}914.4 [teraperbeats]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="trillions of perbeats"} ([Tp](#b){#teraperbeats .tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="teraperbeats"}). The range of sound frequencies which can be [audible](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hearing_range#:~:text=the%20frequency%20range%20that%20can%20be%20heard%20by%20humans) for humans is [~]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="approximately"}[10](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hearing_range#:~:text=humans%20can%20hear%20sound%20as%20low%20as%2012%C2%A0Hz) to [~]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="approximately"}[24000](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hearing_range#:~:text=8%5D%20and-,as%20high%20as%2028%C2%A0kHz,-%2C%20though%20the%20threshold) [p](#per){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="perbeats"}. The period and wavelength that correspond to the frequency chosen by the range input below are 1000 &div; \${iobs} [p](#per){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="perbeats"} = \${parseFloat((1000 / iobs).toFixed(3))} [millibeats]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="thousandths of a beat"} ([mb](#b){#millibeat .tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="millibeats"}) and 735.048 [mv](#v){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="milliomegars"} &div; \${iobs} [p](#per){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="perbeats"} = \${parseFloat((735.048 / iobs).toFixed(3))} [z](#z){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="zem"}.

```{ojs}
//| echo: false
//| label: iobinput
//| class: freqcomponent
// https://observablehq.com/@freedmand/sounds
viewof iobs = Inputs.range([1, 9999], { step: 1,  value: 380, label: "Frequency" })
```

```{ojs}
//| echo: false
//| label: beatinput
//| class: freqcomponent
// https://observablehq.com/@freedmand/sounds
viewof beats = Inputs.range([1, 999], { step: 1,  value: 1, label: "Duration" })
```

```{ojs}
//| echo: false
//| label: iobplayer
//| class: freqcomponent
// https://observablehq.com/@freedmand/sounds
Play((t) => Math.sin(iobs / .864 * t * 2 * Math.PI), beats * .864, iobs)
```

In addition to [p](#per){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="perbeats"}, the limits of human hearing can be expressed in musical [steps](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steps_and_skips#:~:text=the%20difference%20in%20pitch%20between%20two%20consecutive%20notes%20of%20a%20musical%20scale) ([s](#s){#step .tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="steps"}). The equations below convert between [p](#per){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="perbeats"} and [s]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="steps"}. Frequencies less than 12.5 [p](#per){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="perbeats"} have a negative [s]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="steps"} value and are unlikely to be audible outside of carefully controlled laboratory experiments. Similarly, frequencies above 109 [s]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="steps"} or 24320 [p](#per){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="perbeats"} represent the upper limit of the audible range.

Like the ten Dec colors, there are ten frequencies that Dec chooses from the audible range to serve as a set of sound labels. These ten frequencies the Dechromatic scale. 

Dec uses nine [spectral colors](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Visible_spectrum#:~:text=the%20band%20of%20the%20electromagnetic%20spectrum%20that%20is%20visible%20to%20the%20human%20eye) and a tenth color which cannot be defined by a single wavelength, period, or frequency because it is an equal mix of [Red]{.color0} and [Blue]{.color7}. 

To make the [audible](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hearing_range#:~:text=the%20frequency%20range%20that%20can%20be%20heard%20by%20humans) frequency range more intuitive, Humans can hear The typical range for humans extends from Tone [03]{.color3} to Tone [104]{.color4}.a sound wave include its [frequency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frequency#:~:text=the%20number%20of%20occurrences%20of%20a%20repeating%20event%20per%20unit%20of%20time), [pitch](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pitch_(music)#:~:text=a%20perceptual%20property%20that%20allows%20sounds%20to%20be%20ordered%20on%20a%20frequency%2Drelated%20scale) in [p](#per){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="perbeats"}, [period](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frequency#:~:text=the%20reciprocal%20of%20the%20frequency), musical in steps, . From the value selected by the "Frequency" rangeğŸšï¸input below, we can calculate a pitch: , a :

The positive (**+**) and negative (**--**) [indexes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Index#:~:text=an%20integer%20pointer%20into%20an%20array%20data%20structure), [hex]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="hexadecimal"} triplets, and [hÂ°]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="HSL or HSV degrees"} in the table below are used by Dec to labelğŸ·ï¸groups of ten, like [dods]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="days of dek"}, "[top of the [dd]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="deciday"}](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/top_of_the_hour)" [tods]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="times of day"}, and time zones. In addition to colorsğŸ¨, Dec also labelsğŸ·ï¸groups of ten with the [musical notes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Musical_note#:~:text=Chromatic%20scale,-note%20naming%20conventions) that constitute the Dec [chromatic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chromatic_scale#:~:text=a%20set%20of%20twelve%20pitches%20(more%20completely%2C%20pitch%20classes)%20used%20in%20tonal%20music) (Dechromatic) [scale](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scale_(music)#:~:text=any%20consecutive%20series%20of%20notes%20that%20form%20a%20progression%20between%20one%20note%20and%20its%20octave) of the **Ten** **e**qual **t**emperament ([Tenet](#t){#Tenet .tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="ten equal temperament"}) musical system.

# Ten equal temperament (Xet) {.hiddenheading #xet}

[Tenet]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="ten equal temperament"} ([Xet](#t){#Xet .tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="Tenet"}) identifies each Dechromatic scale note with a single-digit integer and expresses all other possible soundğŸ”Šfrequencies as decimal numbers. In contrast, the notes of the [12 equal temperament](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/12_equal_temperament#:~:text=the%20musical%20system%20that%20divides%20the%20octave%20into%2012%20parts) ([12ET](#t){#12et .tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="12 equal temperament"}) musical system have names that consist of a letter from [A]{.colorA} to [G]{.colorG} and often a symbol such as sharp ([â™¯]{.iosevka}), half sharp ([ğ„²]{.iosevka}), flat ([â™­]{.iosevka}), and half flat ([ğ„³]{.iosevka}).

The soundğŸ”Šfrequencies of two consecutive [Xet](#t){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="Tenet"} Dechromatic scale notes always differ by one [s](#s){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="step"}, but the differences between consecutive [12ET](#t){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="12 equal temperament"} chromatic scale notes vary from the [~]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="approximately"}[599]{.color599} [millisteps]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="ten thousandths of an octave"} ([ms](#s){#millistep .tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="millisteps"}) between [A[â™¯]{.iosevka}]{.colorAs} and [B]{.colorB} to the [~]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="approximately"}[1067]{.color067} [ms](#s){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="millisteps"} between [G[â™¯]{.iosevka}]{.colorGs} and [A]{.colorA}. A typical person can reliably distinguish soundsğŸ”Šthat [differ](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cent_(music)#:~:text=Normal%20adults%20are%20able%20to%20recognize%20pitch%20differences%20of%20as%20small%20as%2025%20cents%20very%20reliably) by at least [200]{.color2} [ms](#s){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="millisteps"}.

The rightmost column of the table below shows the [12ET](#t){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="12 equal temperament"} notes that are closest to the [Xet](#t){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="Tenet"} Dechromatic scale notes. [12ET](#t){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="12 equal temperament"} considers [B[ğ„²]{.iosevka}]{.colorBc}, [D[ğ„²]{.iosevka}]{.colorDds}, and [E[ğ„³]{.iosevka}]{.colorDsE} to be [microtones](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microtonality#:~:text=intervals%20not%20found%20in%20the%20customary%20Western%20tuning%20of%20twelve%20equal%20intervals%20per%20octave). The soundğŸ”Šfrequency differences between the nearest [Xet](#t){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="Tenet"} and [12ET](#t){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="12 equal temperament"} notes in the table range from the [8]{.color008} [ms]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="millisteps"} between Notes [9]{.color9} and [A]{.colorA} to the [~]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="approximately"}[87]{.color26div300} [ms](#s){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="millisteps"} between Notes [5]{.color5} and [F]{.colorF}.

# Octave note tone {.hiddenheading #ont}

The image above applies Dec colorğŸ¨labelsğŸ·ï¸to one [octave](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Octave#:~:text=the%20interval%20between%20one%20musical%20pitch%20and%20another%20with%20double%20or%20half%20its%20frequency) of pianoğŸ¹keys. In [Xet]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="Tenet"}, an octave is 10 [s]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="steps"} or 10^4^ [ms](#s){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="millisteps"}. From top to bottom, the text below the image provides the [scientific pitch name](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scientific_pitch_notation#:~:text=a%20method%20of%20specifying%20musical%20pitch%20by%20combining%20a%20musical%20note%20name%20(with%20accidental%20if%20needed)%20and%20a%20number%20identifying%20the%20pitch%27s%20octave), integer [i]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="iob"} soundğŸ”Šfrequency, and integer [mz]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="millizem"} wavelength of the corresponding white key. As octave indexes and frequencies increase, wavelengths decrease.

From the perspective of [Xet]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="Tenet"}, all of the labeledğŸ·ï¸keys in the image above are in Octave [4]{.color4}. Octave indexes in [Xet]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="Tenet"} and [12ET]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="12 equal temperament"} match except for [Xet]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="Tenet"} notes with indexes below [2]{.color2} and [12ET]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="12 equal temperament"} notes from [A[â™¯]{.iosevka}]{.colorAs} to [B[ğ„²]{.iosevka}]{.colorB}.
An octave index is the Xet analog of a clef in staff notation, because both are responsible for setting the reference frame that allows us to interpret the relative pitches of notes as the absolute pitches of tones. 


Clefs in staff notation and octave indexes in Xet set the reference frame that allows us to 


When we append a positive note index that is less than ten to an octave index which is a positive integer, we obtain a [Xet]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="Tenet"} [musical tone](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Musical_tone#:~:text=a%20steady%20periodic%20sound) index.

The tone indexes of the labeledğŸ·ï¸keys in the image above range from [40.069]{.colorAs} to [49.008]{.colorA}. Tone [49.008]{.colorA} is [A4]{.colorA}, the [A]{.colorA} note widely used to [tune musical instruments](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Concert_pitch#:~:text=the%20pitch%20reference%20to%20which%20a%20group%20of%20musical%20instruments%20are%20tuned%20for%20a%20performance). Tone [41.302]{.colorC} is [C4]{.colorC}, the "[Middle [C]{.colorC}](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/C_(musical_note)#Middle_C:~:text=above%20the%20top%20line%20of%20the%20bass%20staff%20or%20below%20the%20bottom%20line%20of%20the%20treble%20staff)" in between the [bass](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clef#Bass_clef) and [treble](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clef#:~:text=the%20most%20common%20clef%20in%20use%20and%20is%20generally%20the%20first%20clef%20learned%20by%20music%20students)ğŸ¼[clefs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clef#:~:text=a%20musical%20symbol%20used%20to%20indicate%20which%20notes%20are%20represented%20by%20the%20lines%20and%20spaces%20on%20a%20musical%20staff) of a [grand staff](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Staff_(music)#Grand_staff).

The mermaid chart below visualizes the structure of the Xet music notation example above it, which is composed of the Xet equivalents of an ascending [Câ™¯]{.colorCs} major [arpeggio](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arpeggio#:~:text=a%20type%20of%20chord%20in%20which%20the%20notes%20that%20compose%20a%20chord%20are%20individually%20sounded%20in%20a%20progressive%20rising%20or%20descending%20order) and a [Câ™¯]{.colorCs} major [chord](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chord_(music)#:~:text=a%20group%5Ba%5D%20of%20notes%20played%20together%20for%20their%20harmonic%20consonance%20or%20dissonance). This arpeggio and chord are also shown beneath the mermaid chart in [staff notation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Musical_notation#Modern_staff_notation:~:text=5%20parallel%20horizontal%20lines%20that%20act%20as%20a%20framework%20upon%20which%20pitches%20are%20indicated%20by%20placing%20oval%20note%2Dheads%20on%20(i.e.%20crossing)%20the%20staff%20lines%2C%20between%20the%20lines%20(i.e.%20in%20the%20spaces)%20or%20above%20and%20below%20the%20staff%20using%20small%20additional%20lines%20called%20ledger%20lines). Whereas staff notation is graphical, Xet notation is [text-based](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plain_text#:~:text=only%20characters%20of%20readable%20material%20but%20not%20its%20graphical%20representation).

42 5 8 5 |
       2 |

Xet vertically aligns chords into columns. A chord can contain either notes that represent tones or the tones themselves. Mixing notes and tones in the same chord is not allowed. The chord in the example above can be written with notes instead of tones because Tone [42]{.color2} sets Octave [4]{.color4} as the default. Each line can have its own default octave.

In the example below, Tone [46]{.color6} sets the default on the middle line to Octave [4]{.color4} but then Tone [50]{.color0} changes it Octave [5]{.color5}. Based on the default, we know the middle note in the chord represents Tone [50]{.color0}. We can then infer the tones represented by the top and bottom notes because chords are always ordered from highest to lowest tone.

```{style="line-height:.9;overflow:visible;font-size:36px;"}
        2 |
46 50 2 0 |
        6 |
```

Column widths are measured in characters. A column of notes has a width of one character. 

The three notes vertically aligned in the column below are the Xet equivalent of a [Fâ™¯]{.colorFs} major chord. Tone [50]{.color0} is able to set the reference frame for all three of these notes, even though they do not all belong to the same octave. Notes that span more than two octaves can be part of the same column but not part of the same reference frame.

4[[4]{.numerator}[4]{.denominator}]{.fraction}| The value of a space depends on the [time signatures](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time_signature#Symbolic_signatures:~:text=an%20indication%20in%20music%20notation%20that%20specifies%20how%20many%20note%20values%20of%20a%20particular%20type%20fit%20into%20each%20measure), which in Xet consist of a top number that defines the number of musical [beats](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beat_(music)#:~:text=In%20music%20and%20music%20theory%2C%20the%20beat%20is%20the%20basic%20unit%20of%20time) per [measure](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bar_(music)#:~:text=a%20segment%20of%20music%20bounded%20by%20vertical%20lines) and a bottom number that determines the number of spaces per musical beat. The number of spaces per measure is the product of the top and bottom numbers.


If a time signature is never specified, we assume there are four beats per measure, four spaces per beat, and thus sixteen spaces per measure. Whenever 

The color labels of  the examples below, one musical beat is indicated by four spaces ([&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;]{.color0625}). Therefore, a single space ([&nbsp;]{.color0625}) is worth a quarter of a musical beat, which is the equivalent of an eighth note in [common time](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time_signature#Symbolic_signatures:~:text=time%2C%20also%20called-,common%20time,-or%20imperfect%20time). In [Xet]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="Tenet"}, a rest is denoted by a null sign (âˆ…). Notes, rests, chords, and their separators are grouped into [measures](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bar_(music)#:~:text=a%20segment%20of%20music) that have a bar (|) on both sides. Measures are grouped into lines that start with an octave index and end with a [newline](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Newline#:~:text=used%20to%20signify%20the%20end%20of%20a%20line%20of%20text%20and%20the%20start%20of%20a%20new%20one) character. Lines separated by empty lines are played sequentially, whereas groups of lines are played simultaneously.

Since each line that represent Octaves 4 and 5, span Notes 40 to 59, and overlap with the majority of the range of 12ET treble clef tones: 41.302 to 61.302. Similarly, two lines representing Octaves 2 and 3 are To cover most of the tone range of the bass clef: 21.302 to 41.302, we need two Xet lines labeled as Octaves 2 and 3, Notes 20 to 39. Of these four lines, the top two cover but the treble clef and the bottom two closely match the bass clef.

The Xet analog of the 12ET treble clef is two lines that represent Octaves 4 and 5, 
to be played separately are separated by spaces and grouped into measures that end with a bar (|). Measures are grouped into lines that start with an octave and [time signature](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time_signature#:~:text=an%20indication%20in%20music%20notation%20that%20specifies%20how%20many%20note%20values%20of%20a%20particular%20type%20fit%20into%20each%20measure) and end with a [newline](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Newline#:~:text=used%20to%20signify%20the%20end%20of%20a%20line%20of%20text%20and%20the%20start%20of%20a%20new%20one) character.

Groups of lines are played together and are separated by empty lines. With four lines, we can cover Octaves 2, 3, 4, and 5 or equivalently Notes 20 to 59, which is close to the range of the [12ET]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="12 equal temperament"} bass and treble [clefs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clef#:~:text=a%20musical%20symbol%20used%20to%20indicate%20which%20notes%20are%20represented%20by%20the%20lines%20and%20spaces%20on%20a%20musical%20staff): [21.302]{.colorC2} to [61.302]{.colorC6}. Of these four lines, the top two are analogous to the treble clef and the bottom two closely match the bass clef. 

All rests except whole rests are followed by a fraction: Â½ for a half rest, Â¼ for a quarter rest, â…› for an eighth rest, and so on. The same goes for notes. # Color and sound {.hiddenheading #cas}

In his [1704]{.color704} book entitled [Optiks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opticks#:~:text=a%20collection%20of%20three%20books%20by%20Isaac%20Newton)[^0], [Isaac Newton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Isaac_Newton#:~:text=,an%20English%20polymath,-active%20as%20a) presented the first [colorğŸ¨wheel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Color_wheel#:~:text=Newton's%20asymmetric%20color%20wheel%20based%20on%20musical%20intervals) and linked its colorsğŸ¨to musical notes. On [[2025]{.color025}[+]{.mono}[080]{.colorD080}]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="May 20, 2025"}, I read [The Color of Sound](https://www.flutopedia.com/sound_color.htm) by [Clint Goss](https://www.clintgoss.com)[^1], which presents a method of connecting musical notes to colorsğŸ¨via their frequencies. The note and colorğŸ¨pairs in that article are similar to those of the Dechromatic scale.

# US customary units {.hiddenheading #ucu}

The [unit conversion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conversion_of_units#:~:text=the%20conversion%20of%20the%20unit%20of%20measurement%20in%20which%20a%20quantity%20is%20expressed) table below shows the [United StatesğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸([US](#u){#unitedstates .tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="United States"}) customary units](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Imperial_and_US_customary_measurement_systems){#us} that Dec redefines. The values in the first column are approximate [fold changes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fold_change#:~:text=measure%20describing%20how%20much%20a%20quantity%20changes%20between%20an%20original%20and%20a%20subsequent%20measurement) from original to redefined units. A fold change of [1]{.color0} means [0]{.color0} [change](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Relative_change#:~:text=compare%20two%20quantities%20while%20taking%20into%20account%20the%20%22sizes%22%20of%20the%20things%20being%20compared). Identical fold changes indicate [US](#u){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="United States"} customary units derived from the same Dec and [International System of Units](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_System_of_Units#:~:text=the%20world%27s%20most%20widely%20used%20system%20of%20measurement) ([SI](#s){#si .tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="International System of Units"}) units.

# Miles per hour (mph) {.hiddenheading #mph}

Unlike Dec and [SI](#s){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="International System of Units"}, the [US](#u){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="United States"} customary measurement system does not use metric prefixes to scale units by [powers of ten](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Power_of_10#:~:text=any%20of%20the%20integer%20powers%20of%20the%20number%20ten). Redefined [US](#u){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="United States"} customary units serve as convenient reference points. [US](#u){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="United States"} customary volume units have intuitive names and scale by [powers of two](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Power_of_two#:~:text=a%20number%20of%20the%20form%202n%20where%20n%20is%20an%20integer).

# Are hectare acre {.hiddenheading #aha}

A square [kilozem]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="a thousand zems"} ([kz^2^](#z){#squarekilozem .tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="square kilozem"}) is 1 [hexakilare]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="sixteen hundred ares"}, 16 [hectares](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hectare#:~:text=a%20square%20with%20100%2Dmetre%20sides){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="hundreds of ares"}, 1600 [ares](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hectare#Are), 40 Dec [acres](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acre#:~:text=k%C9%99r)%20is-,a%20unit%20of%20land%20area,-used%20in%20the), 0.16 square [kilometers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kilometre#:~:text=a%20unit%20of%20length%20in%20the%20International%20System%20of%20Units){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="thousands of meters"}, 0.0625 Dec [square miles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Square_mile#:~:text=US%20unit%20of%20measure%20for%20area), [10^6^]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="a million"} [z^2^](#z){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="square zems"}, or 1 megahexamilliare {.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="1.6 thousand are"} ([Mx](#x){#megahexamilliare .tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="megahexamilliare"}). A [z^2^](#z){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="square zem"} is 1 [hexamilliare]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="1.6 thousandths of an are"} ([x](#x){#hexamilliare .tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="hexamilliare"}), 16 square [decimeters]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="tenths of a meter"}, 1.[7]{.vinculum} Dec [square feet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Square_foot#:~:text=the%20area%20of%20a%20square%20with%20sides%20of%201%20foot)ğŸ¦¶, or 256 Dec square inches. # Drop wineglass keg {.hiddenheading #dwk}

A cubic [decizem]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="a tenth of a zone equatorial meter"} ([dz^3^](#z){#cubicdecizem .tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="cubic decizem"}) is 1 cubic [nanotaur]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="a millionth of a taur"} ([nc^3^](#c){#cubicnanotaur .tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="cubic nanotaur"}), 1 Dec wineglass, 2 Dec ounces, 64 [milliliters]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="thousandths of a liter"} ([mL](#l){#milliliter .tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="milliliters"}), 1000 Dec drops ([g](#g){#gutta .tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="drops"}), or 1000 cubic [centizems]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="a tenth of a zone equatorial meter"} ([cz^3^](#z){#cubiccentizem .tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="cubic centizem"}). A [dz^3^](#z){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="cubic decizem"} of waterğŸŒŠweighs $1\over7$ Dec pounds, 64 grams, or 1000 Dec grains ([g](#g){#granum .tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="grain"}). A Dec ounce ([u](#u){#uncia .tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="uncia"}) of water weighs $1\over14$ Dec pounds, 500 Dec [g](#g){#granum .tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="grains"}, or 32 grams. In Dec, the symbols [g](#g){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="grain"} and [u](#u){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="uncia"} can refer to either volume or mass. Mass divided by volume is density.

If [Leonardo da Vinci](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leonardo_da_Vinci#:~:text=an%20Italian%20polymath%20of%20the%20High%20Renaissance)'s [Vitruvian Man](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vitruvian_Man#:~:text=a%20drawing%20by%20the%20Italian%20Renaissance%20artist%20and%20scientist%20Leonardo%20da%20Vinci) were 4 [z](#z){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="zems"} tall, we could measure 1 [z](#z){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="zem"} from his knees to his feetğŸ¦¶or from his elbowsğŸ’ªto his fingertips. # Body mass index (bmi) {.hiddenheading #bmi}

A normal [bmi](#b){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="body mass index"} ranges from 46.25 to 62.5 $\text {kg}\over\text x$ or 18.5 to 25 $\text {kg}\over\text m^2$. A person with a [bmi](#b){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="body mass index"} above 75 $\text {kg}\over\text x$ or 30 $\text {kg}\over\text m^2$ can be classified as obese. A [bmi](#b){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="body mass index"} of \${kgrains} [kilograins](#g){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="thousands of grains"} &div; \${zem2} x = \${bmi} $\text {kg}\over\text x$ = \${kgrams} kilograms &div; \${meter2} [mÂ²](#m){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="square meters"} = ${bmim2} $\text {kilograms}\over\text m^2$ is considered \${bmiStr}.

# Claude Boniface Collignon {.hiddenheading #cbc}

In [1788]{.color788}, [Claude Boniface Collignon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Claude_Boniface_Collignon#:~:text=a%20French%20attorney%20who%20contributed%20to%20scientific%20and%20social%20reforms%20in%20the%20time%20of%20the%20French%20Revolution) proposed measuring length in [dz](#z){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="decizems"} or [nc](#c){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="nanotaurs"} and tracking time in [deks](#d){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="groups of ten days"}, [dd]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="decidays"}, [md](#d){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="millidays"}, [Âµd](#d){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="microdays"}, and [nanodays]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="billionths of a day"} ([nd](#d){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="nanodays"})[^2]. On [[2025]{.color025}[+]{.mono}[039]{.colorD039}]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="April 9, 2025"}, while searching for units similar to [c]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="taur"} and [z]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="zem"}, I noticed the definition of a [zem]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="zone equatorial meter"}, 1 [z](#z){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="zem"} = [10^-8^]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="a hundred millionth"} [c](#c){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="taur"} = 40 centimeters, in a table of [ten possible length units](https://www.roma1.infn.it/~dagos/history/sm/node12.html) from a [2004]{.color004} [arxiv](https://arxiv.org/abs/physics/0412078) [article](https://www.roma1.infn.it/~dagos/history/sm/sm.html) entitled "Why does the meter beat the second?"[^3].

# Summary {.unnumbered #tldr}

This article introduces the Dec measurement system and describes how Dec uses metric prefixes and the properties of the planet EarthğŸŒto define units based on turns for geographic coordinates, compassğŸ§­directions, dates, times, speeds, distances, areas, volumes, and weights. Each unit has a unique name, such as [Î»](#lambda){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="parallel"}, [m](#m){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="meridian"}, [r](#r){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="rose"}, [y](#y){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="year"}, [d](#d){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="day"}, [b](#b){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="beat"}, [v](#v){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="omegar"}, [c](#c){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="taur"}, [z](#z){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="zem"}, or [x](#x){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="hexamilliare"}.

Dec attempts to bridge the gap, improve interoperability, and faciliate conversion between the [US](#u){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="United States"} customary and [SI](#s){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="International System of Units"} measurement systems by redefining [US](#u){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="United States"} customary units. Redefinition of [US](#u){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="United States"} customary units makes inches [~]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="approximately"}[1.58%]{.color0158} shorter, miles [~]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="approximately"}[0.58%]{.colorMile} shorter, pints [~]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="approximately"}[5.67%]{.colorPint} larger, ounces [~]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="approximately"}[8.21%]{.colorFlOz} larger, and pounds [~]{.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="approximately"}[1.23%]{.colorMass} lighter.

Dec colorğŸ¨labelsğŸ·can convey an impression of a value at a glance. [Xet](#t){.tool data-bs-toggle="tooltip" data-bs-title="Tenet"} soundğŸ”ŠlabelsğŸ·allow us to estimate a value without even having to look at it. Both types of labels can help avoid confusion when [decimal separators](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decimal_separator#:~:text=In%20English%2Dspeaking%20countries%2C%20the%20decimal%20point%20is%20usually%20a%20small%20dot%20%28.%29%20placed%20either%20on%20the%20baseline) appear, disappear, or move due to a measurement unit change such as the addition, removal, or replacement of a metric prefix.

# Cite {.unnumbered #cite}

Of the several different [bibliography file formats](https://pandoc.org/MANUAL.html#specifying-bibliographic-data) supported by [Quarto](https://quarto.org), I recommend storing [citations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citation#:~:text=a%20reference%20to%20a%20source) in [yaml](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/YAML#:~:text=a%20human%2Dreadable%20data%20serialization%20language) files. With the `bibliography.yml` file shown below, you can cite this article and the [2021]{.color021} article entitled [[`chrono`]{.mono .under}-Compatible Low-Level Date Algorithms](https://howardhinnant.github.io/date_algorithms.html) in which [Howard Hinnant](https://howardhinnant.github.io) describes the algorithms that serve as the foundation of Dec dates [@hinnant2021].

```{.yml filename="bibliography.yml"}
---
references:
- id: laptev2025
  author:
    - family: Laptev
      given: Martin
  issued:
    literal: {{< meta date >}}
  title: Dec
  type: article
  URL: https://howardhinnant.github.io/date_algorithms.html
- id: hinnant2021
  author:
    - family: Hinnant
      given: Howard
  issued:
    literal: 2021+183
  title: chrono-Compatible Low-Level Date Algorithms
  type: article
  URL: https://howardhinnant.github.io/date_algorithms.html
...

```

As demonstrated by the previous sentence above and the [References](#references) section below, Quarto citations can include Dec dates. By default, Quarto formats citations according to the [Chicago Manual of Style](https://chicagomanualofstyle.org/) author-date format. Per this format, the citation for this article would appear as [Laptev, Martin](https://maptv.github.io/about). {{< meta date >}}. "Dec." \${decYearP0}+\${decDateP0}. <https://maptv.github.io/dec>.

Instead of using Quarto for citations, you can also prepare a list of references by copying and pasting citations like the one above. In alphabetical order below, you will find the [Observable](http://observablehq.com) notebooks that I adapted into many of the visualizations above. These notebooks did not have an impact on the design or implementation of Dec, but are nonetheless ***note***worthy.

# Glossary {.unnumbered .appendix #glos}

::: {.column-page-right #gloslist}
- [a](#arcbeat){#ab}: arcbeat, a hundred thousandth of a circle, 0.0036 degrees, .216 arcminutes, 12.96 arcseconds
- [b](#beat){#b}: beat, centimilliday, a hundred thousandth of an day, 864 milliseconds
    - [mb](#millibeat){#mb}: millibeat, centimicroday, a thousandth of a beat, a hundred millionth of a day, 864 microseconds
- [c](#taur){#c}: taur, ğœ*r*, 100000 kilozem, 40000 kilometers, nearly the circumference of the Earth, roughly the product of ğœ and the radius of the Earth, approximately the dividend of the surface area and the diameter of the Earth
    - [mc](#millitaur){#mc}: millitaur, *m*ğœ*r*, a thousandth of a taur, 100 kilozem, 40 kilometers
    - [nc](#nanotaur){#nc}: nanotaur, *n*ğœ*r*, a thousandth of a taur, 100 millizem, 1 decizem, 4 centimeters
- [d](#day){#d}: day, a tenth of a decaday, a seventh of week, a fifth of a pentaday, 10 decidays, 24 hours, 100 centidays, 1000 millidays, 1440 minutes, 86400 seconds, 100000 beats, the inverse of a quotidie
    - [dek](#decaday){#dek}: decaday, a group of ten days, 2 pentadays
    - [pent](#pentaday){#pent}: pentaday, a group of five days, half a decaday
    - [dod](#dayofdek){#dod}: day of decaday
    - [dop](#dayofpent){#dop}: day of pentaday
    - [dom](#dayofmonth){#dom}: day of month
    - [dow](#dayofweek){#dow}: day of week
    - [doy](#dayofyear){#doy}: day of year, decaday * 10 + dod
    - [dd](#deciday){#dd}: deciday, a tenth of a day, 2.4 hours, 144 minutes
    - [cd](#centiday){#cd}: centiday, a hundredth of a day, .24 hours, 14.4 minutes
    - [md](#milliday){#md}: milliday, a thousandth of a day, 1.44 minutes
    - [cmd](#centimilliday){#cmd}: centimilliday, a hundred thousandth of a day, 1 beat, 864 milliseconds
    - [Âµd](#microday){#ud}: microday, a millionth of a day, 86.4 milliseconds
    - [nd](#nanoday){#nd}: nanoday, a billionth of a day, 86.4 microseconds
- [Â°](#degree){#deg}: degree
    - [cÂ°](#compassdegree){#cdeg}: compass degree
    - [hÂ°](#huedegree){#hdeg}: hue degree
- [g](#gutta){#g}: granum or gutta, 1 g is a mass of 64 milligrams or a volume of 64 microliters; in Latin, granum means grain and gutta means drop
    - [kg](#kilogranum){#kg}: kilogranum or kilogutta, a mass of 64 grams or a volume of 64 milliliters
- [hex](#hexadecimal){#hex}: hexadecimal, base 16
- [hsl](#huesaturationlightness){#hsl}: hue saturation lightness
- [hsv](#huesaturationvalue){#hsv}: hue saturation value
- [m](#meridian){#m}: meridian, a full circle around the Earth moving North or South; used in the abbreviations a.m. (antemeridian) and p.m. (postmeridian)
    - [dm](#decimeridian){#dm}: decimeridian
    - [mm](#millimeridian){#mm}: millimeridian
- [Î»](#parallel){#lambda}: parallel, a full circle around the Earth moving West or East; the English alphabet equivalent of Î» is the letter "l", which occurs three times in the word "parallel"
    - [mÎ»](#milliparallel){#mp}: milliparallel
- [p](#perbeat){#per}: perbeat, the inverse of a beat, $1\over\text{beat}$, once per beat, every beat, 100000 q; the letter "p" can be flipped vertically to produce the letter "b"
- [q](#quotidie){#q}: quotidie, the inverse of a day, a hundred thousandth of a perbeat; the letter "q" can be flipped vertically to produce the letter "d"
- [r](#rose){#r}: compass rose, a full circle along the horizon, 360 compass degress
    - [mr](#millirose){#mr}: compass millirose, a thousandth of a circle along the horizon, .36 compass degress
- [rad](#radian){#rad}: radian, $1\over\tau$ turns, $360\over\tau$ degrees, $2\over\pi$ turns, $180\over\pi$ degrees
- [rgb](#redgreenblue){#rgb}: red green blue
- [s](#step){#s}: step, a tenth of a two fold change in frequency from one octave to an adjacent octave
    - [Ds](#decastep){#Ds}: decastep, octave, a two fold change in frequency from one octave to an adjacent octave
    - [ms](#millistep){#ms}: millistep, a ten thousandth of a two fold change in frequency from one octave to an adjacent octave
- [sol](#speedoflight){#sol}: speed of light, 647.55170928 kiloomegars, 299792458 meters per second
- [sos](#speedofsound){#sos}: speed of sound, 735.048 milliomegars, 340.3 meters per second
- [ğœ](#tau): 2ğœ‹ or approximately 6.2831853
- [Tenet](#tenequaltemperance){#xet}: ten equal temperance
    - [Xet](#Tenet){#xet}: Tenet
    - [12et](#twelveequaltemperance){#12et}: twelve equal temperance
- [tod](#timeofday){#tod}: time of day
- [t](#turn): turn, 360 degrees, ğœ or 2ğœ‹ radians
    - [ct](#centiturn){#ct}: centiturn, a hundredth of a turn, 3.6 degrees, $\tau\over 100$ or $\pi\over 50$ radians
    - [dt](#deciturn){#dt}: deciturn, a tenth of a turn, 36 degrees, $\tau\over 10$ or $\pi\over 5$ radians
    - [mt](#milliturn){#mt}: milliturn, a thousandth of a turn, .36 degrees, $\tau\over 1000$ or $\pi\over 500$ radians
- [tzo](#timezoneoffset){#tzo}: time zone offset
- [u](#ounce){#u}: ounce, 500 grains, 32 grams, 500 drops, 32 milliliters; originates from the Latin word uncia
- [v](#omegar){#v}: omegar, Ï‰r, 1041.[6]{.vinculum} Dec miles per hour, approximately 1035.62 US miles per hour, 1.[6]{.vinculum} megameters per hour, 0.4[629]{.vinculum} kilometers per second, roughly 1.36 times the speed of sound
    - [kv](#kilomegar){#kv}: kilomegar, kÏ‰r, 1.[6]{.vinculum} gigameters per hour, 0.4[629]{.vinculum} megameters per second, approximately 0.1544% of the speed of light
    - [mv](#milliomegar){#mv}: milliomegar, mÏ‰r, 1.041[6]{.vinculum} Dec miles per hour, roughly 1.03562 US miles per hour, 1.[6]{.vinculum} kilometers per hour, 0.4[629]{.vinculum} meters per second
- [x](#hexamilliare){#x}: hexamilliare, square zem, zÂ², 16 square decimeters, 1.[7]{.vinculum} Dec square feet, 256 Dec square inches
    - [Mx](#megahexamilliare){#Mx}: megahexamilliare, a million square zem, square kilozem, kzÂ², hexakilare, 16 hectares, 1600 ares, 40 Dec acres, 0.16 square kilometers, 0.0625 Dec square miles
- [y](#year){#y}: year
    - [my](#milliyear){#my}: milliyear, a thousandth of a year
    - [yoe](#yearofera){#yoe}: year of era, integer years since the Dec epoch
- [z](#zoneequatorialmeter): zone equatorial meter, zem, 4 decimeters, 16 Dec inches
    - [kzÂ²](#squarekilozem){#kz2}: square kilozem, megahexamilliare, a million square zem, hexakilare, 16 hectares, 1600 ares, 40 Dec acres, 0.16 square kilometers, 0.0625 Dec square miles
    - [kz](#kilozem){#kz}: kilozem, a thousand zem, 400 meters, a quarter Dec mile
    - [zÂ²](#squarezem){#z2}: square zem, hexamilliare, 16 square decimeters, 1.[7]{.vinculum} Dec square feet, 256 Dec square inches
    - [zÂ³](#cubiczem){#z3}: cubic zem, a keg, 64 liters, a thousand wine glasses, a million drops, half a barrel
    - [dz](#decizem){#dz}: decizem, 4 centimeters
    - [cz](#centizem){#cz}: centizem, 4 millimeters
    - [mz](#millizem){#mz}: millizem, 0.4 millimeters
